name: Database Management Systems Lab
references: A Silberschatz, H Korth and S Sudarshan, Database System Concepts, 7th edition, McGraw-Hill, 2010.
R Elmasri, S Navathe, Fundamentals of Database Systems, 7th edition, Pearson,
R Ramakrishnan, J Gehrke, Database Management Systems, 3rd edition, McGrawHill, 2003.
C J Date, An Introduction to Database Systems, 3rd edition, Pearson/Addison Wesley, 2003.
PLSQL accessed through: [https://www.oracle.com/in/database/technologies/appdev/plsql.html](https://www.oracle.com/in/database/technologies/appdev/plsql.html), Accessed on August 2021.
MySQL, accessed through: [https://www.mysql.com/](https://www.mysql.com/), Accessed on August 2021.
PostgreSQL, accessed through: [https://www.postgresql.org/](https://www.postgresql.org/), Accessed on August
experiments: Familiarization with installation of any database management system
Design a database schema and create a database through implementation of Data Definition Language commands - create, alter, drop, rename and truncate.
Querying and modifying the database using Data Manipulation Language commands -select, insert, update, delete.
Implementation of Aggregate Functions – sum, avg, min, max, count. Use group-by and having clause.
Perform join operations – natural join, equi-join, outer join, left outer join, right outer join, inner join and assess the impact of query plans on the performance of join heavy queries.
Perform set operations - union, intersection, set difference.
Implementation of corelated sub-queries and nested queries.
Creating and querying views and materialized views.
Implementation of Data Control Language commands – grant and revoke.
Implementation of Transaction Control Language commands - commit, save point, and rollback.
Implementation of PL/SQL block using variables, operators, data types, control structures.
Implementation of an application with database connectivity for storing and retrieving information.
